awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns problems in the interface between Geometry, Analysis, and the Calculus of Variations. Questions concerning the variational theory of minimal surfaces and its applications will be investigated. Minimal surfaces are among the most natural objects in Differential Geometry. They have encountered striking applications in many other fields, like three-dimensional topology, mathematical physics, complex and conformal geometry, among others. In General Relativity minimal surfaces appear as models for the apparent horizons of black holes. The minimal surface equation plays a very important role as a model for several kinds of nonlinear phenomena in nature. Significant progress in this area has always had a great impact in mathematical analysis and the physical sciences.

The research of this project will advance our basic understanding of minimal surfaces and their general existence theory.  It concerns foundational questions about when these objects exist and how their properties relate to features of the ambient space.  One of the goals is to develop a good understanding of the Morse-theoretic properties of the space of minimal varieties in a given Riemannian manifold. This is to be accomplished by a combination of min-max techniques and topological methods, where the relevant spaces of cycles are defined by means of Geometric Measure Theory.  We will study the existence and basic properties, like the Morse index, of min-max minimal varieties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has supported research of the PI and of graduate  students at Princeton University. The main topic is the existence theory of closed minimal surfaces. Minimal surfaces are central objects in Differential Geometry. Their defining equation also appears in physics, biology, architecture and other applied domains. These surfaces are in equilibrium with respect to forces that tend to minimize the surface area.  We have explored new directions which connect with some classic results on closed geodesics.   The purpose of the research supported by this grant is to consider these objects in more general spaces, more specifically non-Euclidean geometries which could be curved (Riemann spaces).  The most appealing question is to look for closed surfaces, which close up in themselves like the surface of a sphere or of a torus. In the period of this grant we introduced new concepts which relate to dynamical properties of the geodesic flow. In negative curvature we defined an invariant  which is called minimal surface entropy. This is devised to count immersed, closed incompressible minimal surfaces in terms of their areas. This is analogous to the volume entropy which counts the closed geodesics. In positive curvature we constructed new geometries which admit continuous families of minimal surfaces spanning any tangent space. This generalizes the notion of Zoll surface for which geodesics are closed. We have refined our Morse theory for the area functional to cover any closed minimal hypersurface not just those coming from the area widths. This is on how the topology of the space of surfaces relates to the structure of the set of critical points for area. This project was fundamental to support the scientific activities of our group and  helped training graduate students who will become educators.  The research produced with the support of this project gives some important contributions to the discipline of differential geometry with emphasis on developing variational  applications for  the area.
